9.text:
>> Good morning, everyone. Thank you all for
being with us. It is a long walk to greatness,

16.text:
and few living men understand this as well
as former president Barack Obama, his story

21.text:
and life's journey solidified their place
as one of the America's great historical narratives

26.text:
alongside other such narratives as Frederick
Douglass's journey from slave to statesman

32.text:
and Theodore Roosevelt's journey from a sickly
child with asthma to the all American bull

38.text:
moose. President Obama's journey started in
Hawaii, took him to Indonesia, Occidental

44.text:
College, Colombia University, then to Chicago's
south side where his role as a community organizer

50.text:
instilled in him a foundational respect for
civic engagement. After Harvard Law School

56.text:
where he distinguished himself with his election
as the first black president of the Harvard

61.text:
law review he moved to the University of Chicago
where he served as a constitutional law professor

66.text:
for twelve years. In 1996, he was elected
to the Illinois state senate, a policy reformer

73.text:
candidate keen on bipartisanship. His 2004
election to the United States senate saw the

79.text:
scope of his constituency expand and his responsibilities
as a public servant increase. It was a new

85.text:
horizon for himself and for his family.
On February 10, 2007 on the steps of the

93.text:
old state capitol building in Springfield
Illinois, the site of the almost prophetic

98.text:
a house divided speech by Abraham Lincoln
in 1858, Barack Obama announced his candidacy

104.text:
for president of the United States. He won.
And then, in 2012 ‑‑ that's right.

116.text:
(applause and cheering).
He won. And then in 2012, he won again. Both

130.text:
Both times, instilling hope both times promising
change for the lives of every day Americans.

137.text:
Now his legacy is still being understood,
cemented and challenged. But the man stands

145.text:
as ready as ever to assume one of the most
essential roles in democracy, that of the

151.text:
citizen, ladies and gentlemen, I present to
you the 44th president of the United States

156.text:
of America, Barack Obama.
(cheering and applause).

165.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Thank you, hey!
(cheering and applause).

176.text:
Thank you.
Hey! How's it going? Please, everybody have

187.text:
a seat. Have a seat!
So, what's been going on while I've been gone?

190.text:
(chuckles).
It is wonderful to be home, it is wonderful

193.text:
to be at the University of Chicago, it is
wonderful to be on the south side of Chicago.

199.text:
(cheering).
And is it wonderful to be with these young

203.text:
people here. What I want to do is, maybe speak
very briefly at the top about why we are here,

214.text:
and then I want to spend most of the time
that we are together hearing from these remarkable

220.text:
young people who are I think representative
of some amazing young people who are in the

226.text:
audience as well.
I was telling these guys that it was a little

233.text:
over 30 years ago that I came to Chicago.
I was 25 years old, and I had gotten out of

243.text:
college filled with idealism and absolutely
certain that somehow I was going to change

251.text:
the world. But I had no idea how, or where
or what I was going to be doing.

266.text:
I worked first to pay off some student loans,
and then I went to work at the city colleges

275.text:
of New York on their Harlem campus with some
student organizing. Then there were a group

281.text:
of churches out on the south side who had
come together and try to deal with the steel

286.text:
plants that had closed in the area, and the
economic devastation that had been taking

293.text:
place, but also the racial tensions and turnover
that was happening in these communities. So

299.text:
they had formed an organization. They hired
me as what was called a community organizer.

304.text:
And I did not really know what that meant
or how to do it.

310.text:
But, I accepted the job.
For the next three years, I lived right here

315.text:
in Hyde Park, but I worked further south in
communities like Roseland and Auburn Gresham

321.text:
and West Pullman, in working class neighborhoods,
many of which had changed rapidly from white

332.text:
to black in the late '60s, '70s, and full
of wonderful people who were proud of their

344.text:
communities, proud of the steps they had taken
to try to move into the middle class, but

350.text:
were also worried about their futures because
in some cases their kids weren't doing as

355.text:
well as they had, in some cases these communities
had been badly neglected for a very long time.

363.text:
The distribution of city services were unequal.
Schools were underfunded. There was a lack

371.text:
of opportunity. And for three years I tried
to do something about it. I'm the first to

377.text:
acknowledge that I did not set the world on
fire. Nor did I transform these communities

385.text:
in any significant way, although we did some
good things.

390.text:
But it did change me. This community gave
me a lot more than I was able to give in return,

399.text:
because this community taught me that ordinary
people, when working together can do extraordinary

409.text:
things.
This community taught me that everybody has

415.text:
a story to tell that is important. This experience
taught me that beneath the surface differences

428.text:
of people, that there were common hopes and
common dreams and common aspirations, common

435.text:
values, that stitched us together as Americans.
And so even though I, after three years, left

448.text:
for law school, the lessons that had been
taught to me here as organizer are ones that

455.text:
stayed with me and effectively gave me the
foundation for my subsequent political career

466.text:
and the themes that I would talk about as
a state legislator and as a U.S. senator and

475.text:
ultimately as president of the United States.
Now I tell you that history because on the

485.text:
back end now of my presidency, now that it's
completed, I'm spending a lot of time thinking

493.text:
about, what is the most important thing I
can do for my next job? And what I'm convinced

506.text:
of is that although there are all kinds of
issues that I care about and all kinds of

513.text:
issues that I intend to work on, the single
most important thing I can do is to help in

523.text:
any way I can prepare the next generation
of leadership to take up the baton, and to

533.text:
take their own crack at changing the world,
because the one thing that I'm absolutely

542.text:
convinced of is that, yes, we confront a whole
range of challenges from economic inequality

549.text:
and lack of opportunity, to a criminal justice
system that too often is skewed in ways that

558.text:
are unproductive, to climate change, to issues
related to violence, all those problems are

570.text:
serious, they are daunting, but they are not
insoluble.

578.text:
What is preventing us from tackling them and
making more progress really has to do with

586.text:
our politics and our civic life. It has to
do with the fact that because of things like

592.text:
political gerrymandering, our parties have
moved further and further apart, and it is

601.text:
harder and harder to find common ground, because
of money and politics. Special interests dominate

610.text:
the debates in Washington, in ways that don't
match up with what the broad majority of Americans

618.text:
feel. Because of changes in the media, we
now have a situation in which everybody is

628.text:
listening to people who already agree with
them, and are further and further reinforcing

633.text:
their own realities to the neglect of a common
reality that allows us to have a healthy debate,

646.text:
and then try to find common ground and actually
move solutions forward.

654.text:
And so when I said in 2004 that there were
no red states or blue states, they are the

664.text:
United States of America, that was an aspirational
comment, but I think it's ‑‑ and it's

673.text:
one, by the way, that I still believe in the
sense that when you talk to individuals one

677.text:
on one, people, there is a lot more that people
have in common than divides them. But obviously

687.text:
it's not true when it comes to our politics
and our civic life.

692.text:
And maybe more pernicious is the fact that
people just aren't involved, they get cynical.

698.text:
They give up. And as a consequence, we have
some of the lowest voting rates of any advanced

703.text:
democracy and low participation rates then
translate into a further gap between who is

712.text:
governing us and what we believe.
The only folks who are going to be able to

718.text:
solve that problem are going to be young people,
the next generation. And I have been encouraged

728.text:
everywhere I go in the United States but also
everywhere around the world to see how sharp

733.text:
and astute and tolerant and thoughtful and
entrepreneurial our young people are, a lot

745.text:
more sophisticated than I was at their age.
The question then becomes what are the ways

752.text:
in which we can create pathways for them to
take leadership, for them to get involved.

761.text:
Are there ways in which we can knock down
some of the barriers that are discouraging

766.text:
young people about a life of service and if
there are, I want to work with them to knock

776.text:
down those barriers and to get this next generation
to accelerate their move towards leadership

786.text:
because if that happens, I think we are going
to be just fine, and I end up being incredibly

791.text:
optimistic.
So, with that what I'd like to do is to have

799.text:
our panelists here today each tell us a little
about themselves, and what I've asked them

808.text:
ahead of time, and I did give them the question
ahead of time, I asked them to describe for

815.text:
me what it is that they see among their peers
that they think discourages voting participation,

825.text:
paying attention to some of the issues, getting
involved. Do they have some immediate suggestions

832.text:
of the kinds of things that would get young
people more involved and engaged, and discover

841.text:
their voices. Once we have gone through the
entire panel, then we are just going to open

845.text:
it up and we are going to see how it works.
And hopefully, it will be interesting.

850.text:
I'll find it interesting. Hopefully you find
it interesting. All right? So we are going

856.text:
to start with Kelsey.
>> Thank you, Mr. President. Good morning,

861.text:
everyone. It is a absolute honor to be here
with you all. My name is Kelsey, I'm a senior

866.text:
at Loyola University of Chicago, where I spent
the last four years studying marketing with

870.text:
minors in sociology and leadership studies.
I've had the pleasure of being involved on

874.text:
Loyola's campus with a number of different
things going on, and looking forward to graduating

879.text:
in less than two weeks. And pursuing my masters
in higher education and student affairs.

884.text:
And I think to answer your question, my passion
for working with college students does stem

889.text:
from the ability to work with activists and
with community engagement and understanding

893.text:
that college students during that transformative
time is the opportunity for students to learn

898.text:
about these important issues, and really find
their voice, understanding that we can't get

903.text:
discouraged when something doesn't go our
way immediately, but really being able to

907.text:
work towards that end common goal.
>> BARACK OBAMA: Fantastic. Okay.

913.text:
(applause).
>> Good morning, everyone, my name is Ramuel,

919.text:
I grew up in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, I'm a U.S.
army veteran. I major in Sociology with a

926.text:
minor is legal studies at Roosevelt University.
Currently, I’m a research assistant at Roosevelt

936.text:
University focusing on community based collaborative
research projects. We’ve worked on projects

943.text:
ranging from landlord tenant issues to youth
leadership programs and currently we’re

949.text:
working on a project about the day laborer
market in Chicago. It’s a pleasure to be

958.text:
>>Good morning, I’m Tiffany. I was raised
on the south side of Chicago in a low income

965.text:
household. I graduated valedictorian from
Burnside Scholastic Academy, and the top 10

970.text:
from Kenwood Academy. Bronco’s in the house.
I graduated number one from Chicago State

977.text:
University with my bachelors in Chemistry.
And graduated from Chicago State a second

983.text:
time with my Doctorate in Pharmacy. Thank
you. I’ve currently been a community pharmacy

992.text:
manager on the south side of Chicago for the
past 3 years. And I’m also the author of

998.text:
Ten Tactics to Tackle Studying. It’s the
guide to elementary school, high school, and

1008.text:
>> Hi, I'm Max, you can see what they have
made me follow now. I have been involved in

1018.text:
civic engagement and civic life at the University
of Chicago through the institute of politics

1022.text:
which has been an absolute blessing and a
fantastic resource to all of us. The summer

1028.text:
after my first year here they gave stipends,
so that I think the number was 16 of us could

1033.text:
go to Des Moines for the summer of 2015 to
either work with certain press agencies or

1039.text:
with campaigns, that was a really eye opening
experience in terms of having to campaign

1044.text:
directly and how far you can move the needle
by moving one vote in the caucus. I’ll have

1049.text:
more time on this later. I've also been involved
on campus with student government and college

1061.text:
>> Hello, everyone. My name is Ayana Watkins,
I’m the baby of the panel, I'm currently

1068.text:
a senior at Kenwood academy high school.
(cheering and applause).

1077.text:
Throughout my high school career, I've been
involved in numerous student led organizations,

1081.text:
multiple sports teams, etcetera, and outside
of high school I've been involved in a lot

1086.text:
of community‑based organizations to volunteer
my time with the youth as well, and in the

1091.text:
fall I will be attending Paul Quinn College
in Dallas, Texas with multiple scholarships

1096.text:
in my name and I'm also an entrepreneur, I
will say, with my own clothing line.

1105.text:
(applause).
>> Peace and blessings, ya’ll, my name is

1110.text:
Harish Patel, and I live on the northwest
side of Chicago. I arrived as a proud immigrant

1117.text:
around the age of 14 with my mom and sister
from [unintelligible] India. I attended public

1123.text:
schools, and went to University of Illinois
Chicago.

1128.text:
(cheering).
Both for my under... undergraduate studies

1131.text:
and masters in urban planning and policy.
After graduating, I did become a organizer

1141.text:
with somebody in the audience I want to point
out, [unintelligible] a mentor of mine. That

1148.text:
experience led me to run for office, and most
recently, now I work for New America Chicago,

1155.text:
I'm the deputy Director here in Chicago, where
we sort of do what we are doing today. We

1160.text:
infuse new ideas, new voices in public policy
conversation. So I'm looking forward to this.

1166.text:
(applause).
>> BARACK OBAMA: Excellent. As you can see,

1171.text:
we have a extraordinary group here, sharp
young people. But you also notice that they

1178.text:
avoided my question.
So but that's good, because it tees up the

1186.text:
next segment, and look, in the presidential
election, you have maybe half of your peers

1200.text:
voting. In midterm elections, about a third
of your peers vote. I suspect that if you

1214.text:
ask a lot of young people about a wide range
of issues, regardless of where they sit ideologically,

1226.text:
they would say yeah, I'm concerned about the
economy, I'm concerned about foreign policy,

1231.text:
I'm very concerned about this, that or the
other. But a lot of them feel as if their

1238.text:
involvement would not make a difference. It
is not worth their time. And in fact, they

1248.text:
are discouraged but feel disempowered.
So all of you have already shown yourselves

1257.text:
to be willing to get out there and be involved
and to make a difference. I'm curious as to

1265.text:
what is it you think that prompted you to
get involved in some fashion, and also when

1272.text:
you talk to your friends, what is it that
you think is preventing them from doing so,

1276.text:
that might make a difference. We don't have
to go in order. If anybody wants to start,

1284.text:
and I like that in you.
>> Although I'm in high school, a lot of my

1290.text:
peers, I'm a senior so some of my peers were
able to vote this year, but overall, I'm grateful

1296.text:
that I have the opportunity to take courses
at Kenwood Academy High School that involve

1304.text:
political science. We take African‑American
studies, etcetera. But not a lot of schools

1309.text:
have that opportunity.
I would say awareness is something that holds

1313.text:
a lot of our youth back from getting involved,
because, I'm privileged so therefore I step

1320.text:
up and I encourage others to get involved
and to have a voice. But I think the youth

1325.text:
feel like they don't have a voice. That plays
a huge factor as to why the results are the

1332.text:
way they are, if that makes sense.
>> BARACK OBAMA: That makes a lot of sense.

1335.text:
Do you think that as you were coming up, social
studies, civic education, what kids are getting

1345.text:
in the classroom would make a difference?
Do you think that it would make more of a

1350.text:
difference if young people had the opportunities
to volunteer with organizations, to engage

1355.text:
in community service? What is it you think
that would make the biggest difference in

1364.text:
young people seeing, you know what, if I volunteer
for this organization, I might make a difference

1369.text:
in my community, or if I participate on this
issue, somebody might hear my voice and might

1376.text:
actually make a difference.
What do you think would be most effective

1380.text:
in encouraging people?
>> I feel like in order to encourage the youth,

1385.text:
it involves to have a strong support system
behind it to bring the youth up. For instance,

1391.text:
in school, we are taught social studies but
we tend to focus on the mathematics, science,

1399.text:
English, because that is what we are always
brought up on because tests, exams, etcetera,

1408.text:
so social studies and civic education tends
to be pushed to the side.

1414.text:
I feel like it should be encouraged in the
school systems, because majority of our youth

1419.text:
are in school of course and then from there
build outside programs. So you know, from

1425.text:
there ‑‑
>> Yeah. I agree with Ayanna because since

1433.text:
I went to Kenwood too that was the start of
me getting my foot in the door to expand and

1439.text:
do outside things. Also funding after school
programs, and summer programs, because I had

1446.text:
two to three jobs ever since 8th grade every
summer, because, one, you make money, so that

1454.text:
was one, but also to help my resume', help
me get my feet wet to allow me to see different

1462.text:
opportunities, to see if I like being a counselor,
if I wanted to be a cheerleading coach, if

1466.text:
I wanted to be a tutor. So trying different
things every summer helped me to hone in as

1472.text:
to what I want to do with the rest of my life.
After school programs too, the funding for

1477.text:
that, it helps keep the kids off the streets,
hopefully, in Chicago we will have less violence,

1482.text:
since they will have something to do, and
you are also enriching their lives so in school

1486.text:
and after school and also in the summer.
>> BARACK OBAMA: Fantastic. Okay. I'm sorry,

1494.text:
Kelsey, didn't you work, was it the Bronx,
that you worked during the summer? And what

1502.text:
prompted you to, first of all describe what
the experience was and then give us a sense

1509.text:
of what inspired you to do something like
that.

1513.text:
>> Yeah, so I've been blessed at Loyola to
be involved with alternative break immersion

1517.text:
program which sends students on trips over
spring break as well as winter break. The

1522.text:
spring break, of my junior year of college
I spent in the south Bronx working with an

1526.text:
incredible group at an elementary school out
there. We took a group of ten students and

1530.text:
were really their, to enrich their lives for
the week we where there. I think whats so

1536.text:
unique about the program at Loyola, we understand
the privilege that we have to be welcomed

1541.text:
into these communities. We are there to learn
from them.

1546.text:
To understand the experiences the students
are having but to understand how wonderful

1552.text:
so many young elementary school kids are.
I remember the principal at Immaculate Conception,

1557.text:
which was a school that we were at, coming
up to us at the end of the day and said I

1561.text:
hope you realize this is the only week out
of the year the students get to finger paint

1564.text:
because it's too messy with just one teacher
in the room. It took a lot of us there to

1569.text:
be able to make sure they could do that, a
simple thing but really goes to shows the

1573.text:
impact that young people can have in these
communities.

1576.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Ramuel, you were going to
say something, obviously your service in the

1581.text:
military is an example of public service that,
thankfully everybody now appreciates. That

1593.text:
wasn't always the case.
But what I discovered obviously was that once

1602.text:
our veterans take off the uniform, they leave
the service, sometimes people forget how much

1610.text:
talent is there and the need to tap into the
amazing young people that have served in our

1618.text:
military, so that they can work in the community
and continue the leadership that they have

1623.text:
shown while they were in the military.
You have been able to make that transition,

1627.text:
but talk a little about your mind‑set both
when you went into the military and after

1634.text:
you left, how did that change your perception
in terms of your responsibilities to your

1639.text:
community and how you might be able to make
a difference?

1643.text:
>> When I joined the military I joined six
months out of high school. I was working full

1652.text:
time, I wasn't in school, I wasn't in college,
where I come from being in college is a big

1656.text:
deal, graduating is a even bigger deal, but
it's about graduate high school, get a job,

1662.text:
do stuff like that.
I was in the military and I realized there

1667.text:
is so much more to that, and that being afforded
this wonderful opportunity to engage with

1675.text:
so many different people from all over the
country, have so many different views, but

1679.text:
we all share the same purpose, the same goal.
I realized that if I wanted to make a larger

1686.text:
contribution I was going to have to go to
school and so that is what I did.

1692.text:
I served my initial contract, I received an
honorable discharge March 2014. I moved to

1697.text:
Chicago June 2014. I was in Roosevelt August 2014.
I didn't do it by myself. When I got out of

1705.text:
the military, I was part of this program called
veterans upper bound. It is a precollege readiness

1712.text:
program for veterans that need to brush up
on their academic skills before they enter

1718.text:
college.
Being part of that literally saved me taking

1723.text:
extra courses, remedial courses. I benefited
immensely from that. I was fortunate enough

1731.text:
to get a research assistant position at Roosevelt
and that really got me going, because I was

1738.text:
working with different projects, youth, landlords,
I mean it was amazing, because these are regular

1746.text:
folks, and that is something I definitely
wanted to get involved in. To answer your

1753.text:
question about what I think is preventing
youth, I believe what we need to do, we need

1757.text:
to connect personal issues, personal problems
with public issues.

1763.text:
I feel like sometimes, you are working two
jobs and you can't afford day care, is it

1769.text:
not because you are lazy. If we can establish
some sort of connection, demonstrate a connection,

1777.text:
and I'm big on collecting data and numbers
and, listen, 80 percent of people are experiencing

1782.text:
this in your community, and you just don't
know it yet. You don't see it but here are

1787.text:
the numbers, here are the facts. I believe
that is a huge thing that we can do to help

1794.text:
that.
>> BARACK OBAMA: You are making a terrific

1797.text:
point. One of the things that I learned when
I was organizing and it is true for a lot

1804.text:
of young would‑be do‑gooders, you show
up in the neighborhood and your initial instinct

1811.text:
is to tell people what they should be interested
in, instead of spending the first six months

1818.text:
listening and finding out what they actually
are interested in and then connecting, connecting

1829.text:
their immediate needs to the policies that
are having influence on those areas of concern.

1841.text:
The more that you can make concrete for people,
the fact that the reason there aren't enough

1852.text:
after school programs is not just because
they are impossible to set up, but have to

1858.text:
do with budget, and here are the people who
are making the decisions about the budgets,

1864.text:
and the reason that there is a lack of child
care is not because you are the only single

1874.text:
mom who needs child care, everybody needs
child care, but there aren't enough facilities

1879.text:
in place with trained child care providers
and this is what a change in public policy

1886.text:
could do to provide everybody support, that
is when you start bringing people together,

1895.text:
and their voices are amplified. Because what
is certainly true is one voice by itself rarely

1903.text:
changes something, two voices have a better
shot, twenty voices we’re getting somewhere.

1915.text:
But it begins with that listening process
that you’re talking about so that people

1918.text:
feel like they are being heard at the outset.
So I think that’s a great point. Max, were

1927.text:
you somebody who was always interested in
politics generally? Or is this something that

1931.text:
kind of came to you? And since you have been
active in college Republicans, two questions

1942.text:
around that. Number one, do you feel as if
on college campuses sometimes you are not

1950.text:
heard as much as you would like to be? And
because there's, I think there is certainly

1957.text:
a perception sometimes among young people
who are on the more conservative end of the

1965.text:
spectrum that colleges are a bastion of political
correctness, and how do you sort through that,

1974.text:
but also have you found ways in which you
can connect and have a conversation with the

1983.text:
college Democrat, and the person who has a
different point of view, so that we can encourage

1989.text:
better conversations and better understanding
and hopefully more progress.

1994.text:
>> Yeah, so I think being interested in politics,
I don't know that I came from a particularly

2000.text:
politically active family, my mother was involved
in the PTA when I was a child, and that ‑‑

2007.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: PTA is big. PTA is a lot
of work (chuckles).

2013.text:
>> In Connecticut it is blood sport.
(laughter).

2014.text:
I think that the message that something like
that would send is, she didn't need to do

2023.text:
that, she did that because the educational
system and more broadly the community that

2028.text:
was fostered in the town was important to
her and something worth giving her time to,

2033.text:
and something worth going out and no one pays
you to do this, and you take a great deal

2041.text:
of flak.
I certainly honor that commitment. In 8th

2048.text:
grade, which was your first election, in social
studies, we are told ‑‑

2057.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Can I just say ‑‑
(laughter).

2067.text:
That's, but please continue. Ha Ha. In 8th
grade. Go ahead.

2076.text:
>> In 8th grade, we were, I'll pick a different
age.

2086.text:
Each of the beginning of the year picked a
campaign to follow through to fruition, and

2090.text:
each week we did a report for our teacher
on how the candidate had been featured in

2094.text:
the news, any polling information that we
had accumulated, we never got them back. But

2103.text:
it was an interesting process in that it taught
us to care about the news in a time when maybe

2108.text:
that wasn't something that you went home and
watched. It was something that made you more

2113.text:
cognizant of the issues.
I was fortunate enough to go to high school

2117.text:
in New Hampshire where we are pandered to
immensely heavily, and even, it's just part

2124.text:
of the ethos that every four years they care
or that people care about what New Hampshire

2131.text:
has to say.
I think that one of the things that is a shame

2136.text:
in that process is that there is a group that
is active every four years because they are

2142.text:
influential, they are big in the towns they
are from, but you said don't boo, vote, but

2147.text:
- don’t boo, act, might be more apt because
you have people that engage in the process

2154.text:
for every four years and are gone in the in
between period. You have some that you are

2160.text:
brought up to believe your opinion is going
to count for something and then go on to do

2166.text:
big things.
I had a friend whom I went to high school

2169.text:
with, from New Hampshire her whole life, she
is 20 now and she’s a state rep because

2175.text:
she ran for a open seat and that is how it
goes up there. There’s a commitment.

2180.text:
In terms of being involved in politics, I
was fortunate enough to take a year between

2185.text:
high school and college and I worked in Washington,
D.C. in the senate and that is a eye opening

2191.text:
experience because it forces you to confront
in a real way what you believe and why and

2195.text:
you gain a lot of information quickly. I'm
immensely grateful to Kelly Ayotte for the

2200.text:
opportunity. After coming here, that sort
of changed my world view. I thought I would

2206.text:
come here and be a economist like I think
every first year believes at some level here.

2214.text:
That coupled with my time at the institute
of politics which was a good structured force

2219.text:
to show that there was a way, there were many
venues for us to engage civically, let me

2225.text:
explore things like campaigning in Iowa. As
for being Republican on the college campus,

2231.text:
yesterday NBC ran a article about this on
the website and it didn't say who we were,

2238.text:
it said the composition was one Republican,
and the rest were Democrats or progressives.

2242.text:
I had maybe three people send me the article,
and say is it you?

2255.text:
and it is, if you are watching. But I would
say it depends on the setting, whether it's

2261.text:
something I'm particularly forthcoming with.
But at the institute of politics itself, most

2266.text:
people know at this point and certainly in
the beginning of 2016 when caucus season was

2270.text:
going on, those of us who had been in Iowa
and could do caucus math which is as you know

2275.text:
not real math, but the hot comodity in the
room and you would watch the votes tally,

2286.text:
and there were venues certainly where I wouldn't
have brought it up or wouldn't have been particularly

2290.text:
forthcoming with it. I think people suspected
it. But I'll leave that to the other student

2297.text:
government people in the room to confirm or
not.

2299.text:
But, and I don't necessarily know what I was
afraid of, but I think that there is a sense

2307.text:
that if you harbor a view that doesn't jive
with the majority view that you can expect

2314.text:
some level of ostracism from certain people
or you can assume people expect the worst

2320.text:
of you based on beliefs you may or may not
hold. I don't think anyone in this room agrees

2327.text:
with their party a hundred percent of the
time. I might be wrong.

2340.text:
Being a Republican on a college campus is
in and of itself a sort of honor, because

2346.text:
most people don't agree with you and when
you engage in the dorms and in the dining

2350.text:
halls and with those people who are able to
see you, the person, and then you the person

2355.text:
with political views, you are forced to know
yourself well and to do soul searching well,

2360.text:
and to understand why it is that you think
what you think and what parts of your past

2367.text:
impacts what you believe now and might believe
tomorrow.

2371.text:
I think the other thing is there is a significant
empathy gap, not just here but everywhere.

2377.text:
I think most people haven't had in their homes
for dinner in a real way somebody who is significantly

2386.text:
different from them, either politically or
racially or for whatever reason, we have cloistered

2391.text:
ourselves. I think that the liberal bastion
aspect of college campuses can be true. I've

2398.text:
been lucky here, the school is certainly committed
to accepting our thoughts. But I think a broader

2407.text:
societal problem is that as we, if you look
at the county map of 2016, you had a lot of

2413.text:
counties where Secretary Clinton won over
80 percent of the vote and the inverse was

2418.text:
true for the president now. But there is not
understanding, we are not talking, it is not

2424.text:
just that we are reading different news but
it's that we don't talk to each other anymore.

2427.text:
I think it would be good civic engagement
at some point will require a level of civility.

2434.text:
There are a lot of problems with our policies.
(applause).

2441.text:
There is a lot of problems with our politics
that begin at home. I think we blame intransigent

2449.text:
politicians a lot for the failure of us, of
each of us to grasp each other well, so your

2458.text:
mentor when you were a senator, Dick Luger
ultimately lost his primary for that reason.

2466.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Because he talked to me.
>> Because people couldn't stand to see their

2471.text:
member bridge a gap on a human level, and
I think that's sad. I think there is both

2479.text:
a empathy gap and also people see politics
especially in this generation and they say

2483.text:
this is ugly, this is mean, this is something
that you have pretty experienced people doing,

2490.text:
and if the country is a ship and politicians
are sailors maybe the boat moves a degree

2495.text:
either way. But I think the lack of results
stems from a lack of us understanding each

2502.text:
other well. I think Marco Rubio said it well,
you can't run a country when half of it hates

2509.text:
the other. Somehow we have to find ways to
bridge that and to meet people who aren't

2521.text:
(applause).
On this stage, other than me, I guess you

2524.text:
are the other guy who has run for office.
>> The oldest.

2526.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: I wasn't going to say you
are the oldest, you are the other guy who

2530.text:
ran for office and I know you lost, but I
did too once. Right here in this community.

2539.text:
>> I got some gray too.
>> BARACK OBAMA: There you go. But what prompted

2544.text:
you to run for office, which is different
kind of engagement? What did you take from

2550.text:
the experience, did you feel discouraged by
it, did you feel like, okay, this was fun

2555.text:
or if it wasn't fun, then it was worth it?
You would encourage other young people to

2564.text:
take their shot? Tell me a little about your
thought process there.

2568.text:
>> Yeah, and for me, I want to start with
the first time I ever did something that is

2575.text:
considered civically engaged. I was a immigrant,
so I couldn't vote until after Iraq war had

2581.text:
already started, but the first thing I ever
thought I'm doing that is for this country

2586.text:
was protesting the Iraq war. I felt passionately
that we were in the wrong side of history

2591.text:
there. I think you were also at that point
on that side.

2596.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: I agreed with you at the
time.

2599.text:
>> But I couldn't vote. But I felt like a
lot of the times, civic engagement in its

2606.text:
sense gets stuck in the dynamic of voting
or electoral engagement, and doesn't always

2614.text:
expand. I think we have to expand it to maybe
what your mother did, or be on a board of

2621.text:
a nonprofit or, there are tough positions
to have or it's a lot of work there, and I

2627.text:
think, I would hope moving forward we are
thinking about civic engagement beyond voting.

2632.text:
But to directly answer the question around
why I went from protesting to working at a

2640.text:
nonprofit and organizing to thinking about
electoral politics is one of the many routes

2645.text:
that I'm going to engage in, and that happened,
for me, it happened in 2010. It was after

2652.text:
I've done organizing that I saw jargon that
was used against us as young people at that

2659.text:
time, I didn't understand. So that is why
I went back to college to understand public

2664.text:
policy language.
When I ran, it was too, my last name is Patel,

2670.text:
there is not a lot of Patels in office. I
feel like ‑‑

2676.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Lot of Patels in India though.
(chuckles) I'm just saying there are a lot

2679.text:
more Patels than there are Obamas. I want
to be clear here.

2689.text:
>> Agreed. I had a Hussein joke, but I'm not
going to make it (chuckles).

2696.text:
So, at some point, I felt that both or more
than, I don't want to get stuck in this two

2702.text:
party sort of language, but there is a lot
of different personalities of politics that

2708.text:
young people get drawn to and they can't go
beyond the questions they are allowed to ask

2715.text:
within. I wanted to be able to protest and
to run for office and run a small business

2719.text:
and do the organizing, and be able to figure
out which is the most effective way that I

2725.text:
want to, one, live my life and be happy but
also inspire a whole generation of folks that

2732.text:
look like me come from a Muslim background
or South Asian immigrants, and I want most

2737.text:
young people of color to feel they can literally
do anything. That was one of the major reasons.

2742.text:
Also Illinois has a establishment politics
that is really old. Not old in age but old

2749.text:
in thinking. There is a monopoly of power,
money, ideas, that only come from few families

2756.text:
or sometime a few zip codes. I wanted to say
that it's not how we should move forward.

2764.text:
(applause).
>> BARACK OBAMA: A couple of thoughts based

2773.text:
on some of the things that folks have said.
First of all, what you said about there are

2780.text:
a lot of different ways to engage I think
is important, because sometimes people think

2788.text:
if you are not running for office, or it's
not election day, there is no other ways of

2793.text:
getting involved. And the PTA is a perfect
example of the kind of thing that we want

2799.text:
to encourage. There are a bunch of writers
out there and social scientists and thinkers

2807.text:
that would argue that one of the problems
we have with our politics right now is that

2814.text:
the mediating institutions, the unions, the
churches, the PTA groups, the Rotary Club,

2826.text:
a lot of the voluntary organizations that
used to exist, like sororities and fraternities,

2835.text:
that used to bring people in together, to
then work on issues, that those have declined,

2842.text:
and the statistics show that people are less
likely to be involved with various organizations

2850.text:
in their community than they used to be.
What that means is then people don't have

2857.text:
some of the same habits of being together
on a common project, that they used to. We

2866.text:
have become a more individualistic society.
And that I think has some spillover effects

2873.text:
when it comes to both political participation
but also in terms of empathy because you are

2880.text:
interacting with fewer people on a regular
basis.

2884.text:
The second thing though has to do with how
we get information. I want to throw this out

2890.text:
and see what people think. I think a lot of
us who have been in politics for a while,

2899.text:
do see a change from 20 years ago, certainly
30 years ago, where it used to be everybody

2908.text:
kind of had the same information, and we had
different opinions about it, but there were

2913.text:
a common baseline of facts, and that the Internet
in some ways has accelerated this sense of

2923.text:
people having entirely separate conversations,
and if this generation is getting all of its

2931.text:
information through its phones, that you really
don't have to confront people who have different

2938.text:
opinion, or have a different experience, or
a different outlook.

2942.text:
If you are liberal, then you are on MS NBC
and conservative you have on Fox news. You

2950.text:
are reading Wall Street Journal or the New
York Times, whatever your choices are. Or

2959.text:
maybe you are just looking at cat videos which
is fine.

2965.text:
So, one question I have for all of you is,
how do you guys get your information about

2976.text:
the news, and what is happening out there?
And are there ways in which you think we could

2986.text:
do a better job of creating a common conversation,
now that you have got 600 cable stations and

2995.text:
you've got all these different news outlets
that basically are offering one set of opinions,

3005.text:
and if there are two sets of opinions, then
they are just yelling at each other, so you

3009.text:
don't get a sense that there is actual conversation
going on. And the Internet is worse. It's

3015.text:
become more and more polarized.
How much do you think that affects how people

3019.text:
think about issues, and are there ways that
that could be changed, given that most of

3027.text:
your information and certainly for the younger
people coming up behind you, even more, they

3032.text:
are getting their information primarily off
their phones.

3037.text:
>> I think social media has its pros and cons,
in situations like this. For instance, when

3043.text:
it comes to gaining information about what
is going on in the world, it's way faster

3047.text:
on social media than it is on a newscast.
But on the other hand, it can be a downfall

3053.text:
because what if you are passing the wrong
information. Or the information isn't presented

3058.text:
in a way it should be.
That causes a clash in our generation, and

3064.text:
I think it should go back to the old school,
which ‑‑ (chuckles).

3068.text:
>> No phones.
>> I think phones, social media should be

3072.text:
eliminated, because the younger ‑‑ okay,
wait, wait.

3074.text:
(laughter).
I think I should rephrase myself. I think

3080.text:
when it comes to politics and important information,
that can influence younger generations, it

3087.text:
should be organic, so politicians to actually
reach out and actually physically talk to

3094.text:
the community, so it can't be any misconception
on the information being passed, because social

3100.text:
media, going to Twitter or Facebook, anybody
can hack your social media page, that causes

3106.text:
a lot of problems, and to actually go out
to the community, the community will feel

3112.text:
more welcomed. I think that goes back to the
actually getting involved, because to have

3117.text:
somebody shake your hand and to look at you
and talk to you is a more heart felt feeling

3124.text:
to actually listen to what that person has
to say.

3127.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: That is interesting. Kelsey?
>> One of the things you bring up, you said

3132.text:
what I was thinking, is going back to the
basics and having those in‑person conversations.

3137.text:
One of the things that I see the most important
is people being able to listen, to understand,

3142.text:
rather than listen to respond. There doesn't
always have to be a immediate response. Let's

3146.text:
understand, where both viewpoints are coming
from.

3147.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: I learned that in marriage,
by the way.

3153.text:
(laughter).
Just a tip for you young people. Listening

3159.text:
to understand, rather than listening to respond.
That will save you a lot of heart ache and

3165.text:
grief. Sorry. A little tip there.
>> I think it's something our generation,

3173.text:
we find it easier to hide behind Facebook
screens, behind Twitter, between Instagram

3177.text:
posts but being able to have in‑person conversations
and listen to the other side is the only way

3182.text:
at the end of the day we are ever going to
get anything done.

3187.text:
>> It's important to engage with the leaders
of that community, and instead of going in

3193.text:
there and one thinking because it affects
you and another city doesn't mean it's going

3200.text:
to be the same dynamics in this neighborhood,
it is important, I want to help but I need

3207.text:
to be humble and listen to people that have
lived through it and have a clearer understanding

3216.text:
of what is needed. Dialogue is important,
deliberation is important. You need to critically

3223.text:
analyze people's views. And then you can create
a plan off of that. I definitely think as

3231.text:
far as where you get your news from, diversity
is important. Not every news station that

3240.text:
leans Republican is horrible. It's nice to,
you need to understand how the other side

3248.text:
thinks.
But yeah, I really believe that, not shunning

3254.text:
other people that have different views than
you, recognizing that yes, I do want to help,

3259.text:
but respect the fact that there are people
that have been here longer than you that have

3264.text:
lived these issues and you need to work with
them, instead of outsourcing their help with

3270.text:
stuff.
>> BARACK OBAMA: Any other thoughts? Max,

3274.text:
you have something to say on this?
>> Yeah. There was an interesting, either

3280.text:
in the Journal or Times shortly before the
election that they made a generic Republican

3286.text:
and Democrat Facebook page and showed you
the news articles that would be in their news

3293.text:
feed, that they could go and see.
The facts of the case that we now live in,

3301.text:
there is rumors that we don't have facts anymore
in society, I'm in a linguistics class here

3306.text:
called Truth. The first class, they played
a documentary with a man who was a defense

3315.text:
attorney, in the Bronx during the '70s, and
he will tell you that if you ask somebody

3321.text:
what shape a table is you can get three answers,
if you are sitting at the table it's probably

3326.text:
a rectangle, if you are underneath it, who
knows, it's the ceiling, and then if you are

3330.text:
looking at it from the side, it has a rounded
edge, so clearly it's a semicircle.

3336.text:
I think that is basically where we are with
the news. I don't know if the coverage were

3342.text:
of the same issues that people would find
factual difference anyway. I think part of

3349.text:
the problem is that we don't agree on what
the issues are that are pressing and facing

3353.text:
the country. I don't know how you get there.
But I don't think that a national dialogue

3360.text:
necessarily starts on‑line or starts in
the press. I think it starts door to door.

3365.text:
Maybe that is in how people go about campaigning.
Now it's easy to know you have numbers if

3372.text:
you can only get them to show up and there
is no onus to work to get somebody else to

3377.text:
persuade you that your point of view is correct.
Instead there is a incentive to spend millions

3384.text:
of dollars in advertisement saying if my opponent
is elected, the apocalypse will occur, rivers

3390.text:
will run red and Hawaii will sink. The ship
only has to move one degree to make those

3399.text:
things happen.
At all levels there has to be a civic conversation

3405.text:
and people have to be willing to talk to each
other again. Maybe it starts in middle school,

3411.text:
where you see in a class who has differing
views and commit part of social studies time

3417.text:
to have people talk through issues of the
day and why they think what they think. We

3420.text:
have to get to a place where people can talk
to each other again.

3423.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: That has been a running theme.
I will say this. The reason I was able to

3433.text:
run for the United States senate was because
in addition to my base here in Chicago, I

3444.text:
had spent a lot of time traveling around the
state. Over time, I got to know people in

3452.text:
parts of Illinois that would today be considered
red and I lucked out effectively that I was

3462.text:
kind of under the radar screen, so political
ads didn't characterize me. People would meet

3469.text:
me, even though I'm this Chicago lawyer from
a liberal district with an Arab sounding name

3478.text:
and, but I'd show up, and then you would have
a conversation.

3486.text:
You would talk about their kids and basketball
and what was happening on their jobs, and

3495.text:
people got a sense that my frames of reference
and my values were not so different from theirs.

3503.text:
that gave me the ability is to break through
assumptions that people might otherwise have.

3511.text:
Iowa is the same way, I'm traveling around
the state, as you know from having worked

3517.text:
there, it's retail politics. You are going
door to door just talking to people. We didn't

3526.text:
have a huge amount of money particularly initially
for TV ads, so it was just meeting people

3534.text:
and that does change people's assumptions
when they get a chance to know somebody directly.

3541.text:
Part of what we have to figure out is, how
do we create greater opportunities. Now, that

3549.text:
is true, between red parts of the state and
blue parts of the state, it's true even within

3557.text:
the City of Chicago. I was yesterday with
a group of young men who are part of a program

3570.text:
designed to give them opportunities and pathways
away from violence and crime. These are some

3579.text:
young people from 18 to 24. All were African‑American
except one who is Latino, many of whom had

3590.text:
already prison records, and had done some
pretty rough stuff, several of whom had already

3600.text:
been shot, in some cases multiple times, none
of whom had grown up with fathers, many of

3607.text:
whom had effectively been orphaned when they
were very young.

3612.text:
So, this would be the stereotypical profile
of somebody who has good likelihood of shooting

3624.text:
or getting shot here in Chicago, as part of
the violence that has been plaguing the city.

3632.text:
What was striking, when you sat down with
these guys, was they are young people, and

3640.text:
if you had listened to them talking, you would
recognize them as not that different from

3646.text:
any other young man 18 to 24. What was different
was their circumstances. They had grown up

3655.text:
in some cases in foster care, or their mother
was a drug addict, and they had been neglected.

3667.text:
So, even within the city boundaries a lot
of times we will characterize our neighbors

3679.text:
as something entirely different than us, that
we can't understand and that we are afraid

3685.text:
of and that we can't communicate with them,
political rhetoric reinforces that.

3690.text:
And they need to be heard too, because if
the six of you had been in that conversation,

3700.text:
you would have come away not saying, these
are some thugs or super predators that I can't

3707.text:
relate to, you would actually say, man, if
I had gone through what they went through,

3714.text:
I'm not sure how things would have worked
out for me, either. And that creation of empathy

3719.text:
then promises a different kind of civic response
and political response than the one that so

3727.text:
often we have.
That hearing other people I think is vital,

3732.text:
and the question is, are there ways in which
we can create opportunities to do that for

3738.text:
more young people earlier on, before the lines
of division start hardening. Tiffany, you

3745.text:
were going to say something.
>> Yeah. So to add on to this about you being

3749.text:
in the community and what was said about meeting
officials, I met you before in high school.

3755.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Is this another story about
how old I am?

3757.text:
(laughter).
>> No, no, no! But I was singing with Kenwood

3762.text:
academy concert choir, I was at a breakfast
downtown. I actually walked up to one official

3769.text:
because I had seen him on TV, and he put his
finger up and said no he can't talk to me

3774.text:
right now, I saw you, hi, Mr. Obama, can
I please take a picture with you, you said

3780.text:
no, I'm like what is going on, they say on
TV they care about people and then in person

3786.text:
they don't want to talk to me, but you said
no, not until you tell me your name first.

3791.text:
And you shook my hand.
>> BARACK OBAMA: Oh! Whew!

3802.text:
>> you shook my hand, you talked to me a little
bit and all of that helped inspire me too,

3805.text:
that he is not just a face on TV, you know
they may shake your hand in public but then

3811.text:
you don't feel connected like Ayanna was saying.
That helped me too want to be involved and

3816.text:
listen to what you have to say because I felt
that you cared about someone, a little black

3820.text:
girl from Chicago like me.
Going back to what Max was saying, in pharmacy

3827.text:
school they did show us different bills and
we went for pharmacy week and lobbied in Springfield.

3834.text:
The school, Chicago state actually did instill
in us how important it was to fight for our

3840.text:
rights, because if I'm going to school to
be a pharmacist, you never know, they may

3843.text:
take away that I can't dispense drugs anymore,
and I had no say in it.

3848.text:
I do think what Max was saying as to bringing
it into the schools will be very beneficial.

3853.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Excellent. All right. Well,
I suspect, I'm a little out of practice, so

3860.text:
I didn't check to find out how long we are
supposed to be here.

3865.text:
(laughter).
But I'm having fun. Where is the Chairperson?

3870.text:
How long are we supposed to be here? What
I was thinking is, is that I've been asking

3877.text:
a lot of questions. I should give you guys
an opportunity to ask me a couple of questions,

3885.text:
before time is up.
So, anybody want to take a shot? Well, not

3893.text:
you. We are talking to young people though.
But it's great to see you. I didn't mean to

3900.text:
imply that you are not young. But ‑‑
(laughter).

3904.text:
I'm just saying. Go ahead.
>> I have definitely have a question. I've

3911.text:
been working on this project called Latino
union, community organization, on northwest

3917.text:
side of Chicago. We have been working on surveying
day laborers on the corners where they search

3924.text:
for work.
I started in September. Initially it was difficult,

3932.text:
because again I was never a day laborer. I
went with a organizer from Latino union, so

3937.text:
it definitely helped, a icebreaker, he understood
the dynamics at the corner.

3945.text:
After November, it was extremely difficult
to talk to these men, and I already had conducted

3952.text:
almost say 20 surveys up until then, and I
continued until March, but between November

3959.text:
and March, it was just the presence of me
being out there with a clipboard was ‑‑

3965.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: Made them nervous.
>> Exactly. Me, I was talking to them in Spanish,

3972.text:
explaining why I'm there, but because of everything
that was going on it was almost like, okay,

3977.text:
yeah, but you are just one person.
So my question to you, Mr. President, is,

3983.text:
how could you bring these people not like
me, I want to engage with them, and I'm doing

3990.text:
what I can, but how can I tell these men and
women that they are, to come out of their

3998.text:
shadows, because they are already in the shadows
and now they are in the shadows even further

4001.text:
and how can I tell them, it's okay to tell
me your working conditions and nothing is

4008.text:
going to happen to you?
>> BARACK OBAMA: Well, in some ways you already

4013.text:
answered your own question. This is a matter
of trust.

4019.text:
For you to finish your research project, you
are going to need somebody that they trust

4025.text:
to introduce you to them. And one of the things
that I learned as an organizer and then as

4034.text:
a politician, is your ability to create trust
and relationships is the thing that makes

4045.text:
all the difference in being able to have an
impact. That is hard to do in this current

4055.text:
environment. But it's not impossible. So it
may be their priest, it may be somebody that

4064.text:
they worked with that you know, whose legal
status is less at risk.

4074.text:
I think generally speaking, immigration is
a good example of an issue that stirs up so

4084.text:
much passion, and sometimes misinformation,
that it's hard for us to have a good healthy

4092.text:
conversation about it. The interesting thing
is historically when you look at surveys,

4101.text:
the overwhelming majority of Americans believe
that America is a nation of immigrants, and

4108.text:
that immigration has contributed to the wealth
and prosperity and dynamism of the country.

4116.text:
The majority of Americans also believe that
immigration should be lawful and orderly,

4122.text:
that it shouldn't be haphazard. So sometimes
they feel frustrated if it is perceived that

4133.text:
folks are breaking the rules or cutting the
line essentially.

4139.text:
So I think it's important for those who support,
as I do, immigration reform and pathways to

4148.text:
citizenship for folks who are here, not to
assume that everybody who has trouble with

4154.text:
the current immigration system is automatically
racist. That is an example of us being able

4161.text:
to listen.
I think for those who are concerned about

4170.text:
undocumented workers coming in, whether it's
across the border or more typically these

4176.text:
days overstaying visas, it's important for
them to also appreciate the degree to which

4183.text:
these are overwhelmingly families who are
just looking for a better life for their children.

4192.text:
I always used to say, sometimes in crowds
that where folks didn't want to hear it, that

4200.text:
it's not like everybody in Ellis Island had
all their papers straight. The truth is the

4207.text:
history of our immigration system has always
been a little bit haphazard, a little bit

4214.text:
loose, a little bit determined by, did the
country want more workers, economic imperatives,

4226.text:
sometimes it was driven by biases.
If you look at what was said about Irish,

4237.text:
when they were coming here, in the wake of
the potato famine, they talked about them

4244.text:
the same way that you hear people talking
about immigrants today. This is an example

4250.text:
of where everybody being able to see the realities
of immigrants as people, not as some other,

4263.text:
is important, but it also requires us who
are advocates on behalf of immigrants to have

4269.text:
some respect for people who you may be able
to win over, if you can argue that we are

4277.text:
going to create an immigration system that
is fair, but still allows people to come here

4284.text:
and achieve some sort of opportunity.
But the short term problem you have of finishing

4290.text:
your survey is you have to find somebody who
trusts you and you might want to put away

4297.text:
the clipboard, and get to know them a little
bit before you start just surveying them.

4302.text:
When I was organizer, one of the things we
used to always say is, don't knock on people's

4306.text:
door with a clipboard. Because they don't
know you, they don't know if you are the tax

4312.text:
You know. Or they don't know how long this
thing is going to take. They are in the middle

4319.text:
of a ball game or, you know. Watching reruns
of Desperate Housewives or something and they

4327.text:
are really into it and all of a sudden there
is the guy with the clipboard, I don't want

4331.text:
to hear that.
>> You want to do one more?

4334.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: We got time for two or three.
>> As somebody who lost a election I'd like

4342.text:
to understand your perspective on failure
or more of the things with media that I see

4350.text:
is I'm worried about young people who claim
a certain thing in high school and then they

4355.text:
get into college and, or they get older, and
these claims sort of stay with them, what

4360.text:
they tweeted, what they Instagram and what
they Snapchatted and they don't get to grow

4365.text:
in there ideas or thoughts. And people will
bring that up. Same thing with elected officials.

4371.text:
You are running for office. You are not a
feminist at 19 and you understand the word

4376.text:
means something positive, now I'm a feminist.
Now that I read the Belle Hooks book and I

4384.text:
get it. How do you think about the concept
from using technology and young people but

4392.text:
also as somebody who has a public facing life,
long term.

4397.text:
>> BARACK OBAMA: I've got a couple responses.
First of all, with respect to failure, it's

4404.text:
terrible. But necessary. If you are going
to try something hard, if you are putting

4411.text:
yourself out there in some way, there are
going to be times where you screw up or you

4417.text:
don't succeed. Or there are times where you
do everything right and you still don't succeed.

4423.text:
But that is not just true of politics or running
a non‑for‑profit, that is true, some of

4430.text:
you talked about being entrepreneurial. If
you are starting a clothing line, that's a

4435.text:
cut throat business. I'm sure you, I have
every confidence that you are going to succeed

4441.text:
at some point, but you will go through some
failures. I think that the most important

4450.text:
thing, and this is a little bit of a cliche,
but sometimes cliches are true, is to learn

4458.text:
from those failures, and to have a sense of
resilience and be able to examine what is

4465.text:
it that I did not succeed at, why didn't I
succeed, and what do I need to do better?

4473.text:
The political race I lost was to a congressman
Bobby Rush, and when I, it's interesting because

4484.text:
I'm writing a book right now, about my political
journey and when I was writing, when I thought

4492.text:
about that race, what I was reminded of was
the degree to which that was probably the

4503.text:
sole time in my political career where I think
I ran more just because it was the next thing,

4511.text:
rather than running because I had a good theory
of what it is that I wanted to do.

4518.text:
And this is a mistake I think a lot of folks
who get into politics make. When I see White

4524.text:
House interns or talk to young people, I always
tell them, worry less about what you want

4530.text:
to be, and worry more about what you want
to do.

4542.text:
you are more concerned with, I want to be
a congressman, or I want to be a senator,

4550.text:
or I want to be rich, then some people may
succeed in chasing that goal, but when they

4564.text:
get there, they don't know what to do with
it.

4567.text:
If they don't get there, they don't have anything
to show for it. But if you are worrying about,

4573.text:
I want to improve education, in low income
neighborhoods, or I want to deal with climate

4582.text:
change and help save the planet, then whatever
you are doing in pursuit of that goal in and

4590.text:
of itself is going to be worthwhile and it's
going to teach you things. It's going to put

4595.text:
you in a position to have an impact, and then
if it turns out as a result that you also

4600.text:
end up being successful in politics or whatever
thing you are pursuing, then so much the better.

4611.text:
The most successful business people that I
know of, Bill Gates didn't start off saying

4616.text:
I want to be the richest man in the world,
he started off saying to himself, I really

4622.text:
think these computers are cool, and I want
to write cool software. That is what he wanted

4628.text:
to do. Worked out well for him.
But so I think that's with respect to the

4639.text:
failure issue. If you are focused on giving
of yourself to accomplish something, then

4646.text:
even when you fail at a particular objective,
you are still succeeding in learning about

4653.text:
how you can accomplish those goals. And it
doesn't just become about you. In terms of

4665.text:
how to deal with the fact that as you grow
up, you are going to learn and change and

4679.text:
evolve, in all kinds of ways, and that that
is healthy and normal but the problem now

4686.text:
is with the Internet that past is always there,
one way to think about it is just to own it,

4699.text:
because I mean it is true that if you had
pictures of everything I had done when I was

4703.text:
in high school, I'd probably, I probably wouldn't
have been president of the United States.

4709.text:
(laughter).
So, I would advise all of you to be a little

4714.text:
more circumspect about your selfies, and what
you take pictures of. Just a suggestion. But

4728.text:
it is a real problem. Everything is searchable,
and, look, this is one of the biggest challenges

4734.text:
of being in public life generally. I wrote
a book about my early journey, Dreams from

4745.text:
My Father a long time ago, and because I had
been pretty honest about the struggles I went

4753.text:
through as a young man, when I ran for office
and there was some big reveal about, oh, the

4762.text:
guy smoked pot, it's like, yeah, I know, it's
in my book.

4765.text:
(applause).
And I learned, I learned from that, I didn't

4775.text:
sugarcoat it, I didn't suggest that somehow
it had been something that I recommend for

4783.text:
everybody, but that is what teenage kids did
at that age when I was, where I was growing

4789.text:
up, not everybody, some were wiser than me.
I wasn't that wise.

4794.text:
So, I think the best you can do is to own
your life, and your mistakes, and the changes

4805.text:
that you go through. It doesn't mean that
it's always pleasant to have people just all

4812.text:
up in your business. You know, I must have
had at this point six, seven biographies written

4821.text:
about me, and I'm sure there are more coming
out. And generally speaking, one of the frustrations

4829.text:
is, is that like my life wasn't that exciting
up until, until I guess I was President. You

4838.text:
know, so I didn't have, you know, these amazing
experiences. I didn't really accomplish all

4848.text:
that much when I was in high school or in
college.

4854.text:
So folks then go around and they are looking
for stuff, and then they try to dramatize

4861.text:
things that are kind 
of routine, you know. There is a part of you

4871.text:
that kinda says, why would you care about
this? It's not that interesting.

4877.text:
But you know what? That's the nature of the
business in some ways.

4883.text:
Now, that is for people who are running for
office. That is not true for most of you in

4889.text:
terms of wanting to get involved and participate.
There is something unique about politics that

4898.text:
is frustrating, but I don't think there is
that much you can do about it, other than

4902.text:
just to own the fact that you are human, and
you make mistakes, and you grow. I think most

4910.text:
people understand that. Certainly most people
of this generation who understand that a lot

4916.text:
of stuff ends up on the Internet, I think
are probably more forgiving about those kinds

4924.text:
of issues.
So, well, I have to say that there is a reason

4931.text:
why I'm always optimistic, even when things
look like they are sometimes not going the

4937.text:
way I want, and that is because of young people
like this. And it gives you I think a sense

4942.text:
of what is possible for this country.
My hope is, is that working with young leaders

4953.text:
like this, the organizations that, and universities
and high schools and nonprofit organizations

4960.text:
and community groups that are getting them
engaged, that my foundation and presidential

4968.text:
center will be able to provide more and more
pathways for young people getting involved,

4975.text:
so that when somebody like me,35 years ago
decides that I've got something to contribute,

4985.text:
that we will have eased the path a little
bit for them. And maybe they can learn from

4990.text:
some of the mistakes that I made and others
have made, so that they can seize the future.

4996.text:
But I really appreciate the outstanding contributions
all of you made. I'm excited to see what you

5001.text:
all do in the future. Can everybody give them
a big round of applause? Thank you, everybody.
